review.title: A Continuous-time Mutually-Exciting Point Process Framework for Prioritizing Events in Social Media
review.abstract: The overwhelming amount and rate of information update in online social media is making it increasingly difficult for users to allocate their attention to their topics of interest, thus there is a strong need for prioritizing news feeds. The attractiveness of a post to a user depends on many complex contextual and temporal features of the post. For instance, the contents of the post, the responsiveness of a third user, and the age of the post may all have impact. So far, these static and dynamic features has not been incorporated in a unified framework to tackle the post prioritization problem. In this paper, we propose a novel approach for prioritizing posts based on a feature modulated multi-dimensional point process. Our model is able to simultaneously capture textual and sentiment features, and temporal features such as self-excitation, mutual-excitation and bursty nature of social interaction. As an evaluation, we also curated a real-world conversational benchmark dataset crawled from Facebook. In our experiments, we demonstrate that our algorithm is able to achieve the-state-of-the-art performance in terms of analyzing, predicting, and prioritizing events. In terms of interpretability of our method, we observe that features indicating individual user profile and linguistic characteristics of the events work best for prediction and prioritization of new events.

sections.heading: III. BACKGROUNDS ON TEMPORAL POINT PROCESSES
sections.text: Time is an important factor in the study of events in social networks. It could be argued that any well-developed statistical method such as linear or ridge-based regression, probabilistic models, etc. with waiting times of events can be used to perform an analysis of event dynamics on a sample of users. The reason why these standard statistical methods do not correspond to time-dependent events is a fundamental problem that is almost always encountered in dealing with such problems: when the investigation of users ends and the analysis begins, one is left with a series of both complete and incomplete observations. The event in question happened for a subset of users and not for the rest, but one has no knowledge of whether the event will happen to the rest in the future. sections.heading: E. Features
sections.text: The proposed framework is general enough to work with any feature taken from users (or even without any feature in its simplest form), such as their profile information and their interaction history. In this subsection, we briefly introduce the features we use to parameterise the influence. Remember, we have different influence parameters for posts and comments, namely the editor's influence and the content's influence. We believe that the editor's social influence on the user is a function of the social status of both, as well as their history of interactions. Therefore, character-based influence has to do with characteristics of the publisher and the user, such as their popularity, knowledge or level of activity; on the other hand, relationship-based influence is a measure of the interactions between the publisher and the user, such as common interests and activities. Table II shows the features we have extracted for each of these two elements of influence.

sections.heading: A. Dataset
sections.text: We examine our model based on discussion cascades crawled out of Facebook groups. Facebook groups are online communities of people who share interests or concerns, such as colleagues, classmates, celebrity fans, parents, etc. People join Facebook groups to share updates, photos, and documents, and receive feedback about them. With hundreds of millions of online groups, each with tens to thousands of members, discussing topics ranging from animal care to philosophy, Facebook provides us with abundant ongoing conversations between a well-known group of people to facilitate the study of conversation dynamics in online social media. We have collected a corpus of about 50,000 conversations recently drawn by Facebook, with over 1 million comments, involving about 25,000 people. Ours is the only corpus of Facebook conversation data available so far for a study. The groups selected for this study were 16 open groups (groups whose contributions can be viewed by non-members) selected to cover a range of topics and populations presented in Table III.

sections.heading: VII. DISCUSSION
sections.text: Our model can be easily expanded to capture different decay rates for users or groups. In addition, we can use any technical feature set or even no feature to learn the Hawkes model. It is noteworthy that the post and comment in this essay can be considered an abstraction of any activity on social networks such as likes, comments, photos, status distribution, etc. It is easy to generalize the model to capture different types of actions on social networks and model their interaction by coupling their intensities. In our experiments, we only used the usual notion of posts and comments to establish the framework and show its effectiveness in conversation dynamic analysis. As a future work, we would like to explore other methods to tackle limited data, such as prior knowledge and hierarchical parameter learning.
